DOC.brief_summary: The purpose study test effectiveness culturally-tailored Internet-based program help American Indian ( AI ) tribal college student quit smoking .
DOC.brief_title: Web-based Smoking Cessation Program Tribal College Students
DOC.detailed_description: Many approximately 25,000 American Indian ( AI ) student enrol tribal colleges/universities US arrive smoker . A 2011 study high school senior report smoking prevalence among AI student approximately 40 % , high rate among racial ethnic group study . Although prevalence data smoking among AI college student limited , study show majority smoker high school continue smoke reach college . Prohibited marketing adolescent child , tobacco industry recent year shift intense marketing college student , result increase smoke rate among . The transition college provide amble opportunity young adult acquire new harmful habit . Many habit seem alien young AIs : Cigarette smoke number one cause preventable death among AIs . Cancer second lead cause death among AIs , lung cancer lead cause cancer death AI men woman . Cultural factor , socioeconomic circumstance , lack culturally-tailored cessation program American Indian tribal college student prevented access effective intervention promote smoke cessation . To date , study focus method encourage smoke cessation among tribal college student randomized clinical trial yet conduct . To address public health deficit , propose innovative , effective , culturally individually-tailored smoke cessation program promote cessation . Primary aim : To test effectiveness culturally-tailored internet-based smoking cessation intervention ( I-ANBL ) compare internet-based heart healthy diet ( I-FV : fruit/vegetable ) control condition randomize control trial Tribal College student . Our hypothesis American Indian tribal college student randomize culturally-tailored smoking cessation arm significantly high 7-day point prevalence abstinence ( define cigarette past 7 day , biochemically verify ) rate 6 month receive heart healthy diet intervention .
